author: {'steamid': '76561198071594947', 'num_games_owned': 1394, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 16996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10048, 'last_played': 1653294324}
review:
I have never played Golf in real live, only 2-3 times mini-golf in my life.
I have played Golf Games since 1990 starting with Leaderboard Golf on the Commodore C-64.
But I was never an 'enthusiast'. I only play Golf Games 'than and now'.' I see them as a kind of relaxed time-waster. More relaxing as Break-Out/Arkanoid (if this makes sence).
For me, as a single player video game player, I see them as a kind of relexation-reflex game.

I have a descent gaming rig (i-4790K OC + GTX980 16 GB ram blabla).

I own both. The Golf Club and Perfect Golf. I don't care about this Nicklaus. (Nicklaus has to stock my footware on 6th of december with sweets but don't interfere with my video games ;)

TGC: 42 hours play time
JNPG: 167 hours play time

Both are nice games. I play JNPG more often.
Why?

First. 
JNPG has 3-click. 
I dont like game-pads. 
(let the filthy console peasants or perverse masochistic 'real-life' mouse-swingers be happy with their raison d'etre, But least at last maintain our aristocratic way of computer golf game control  since time immemorial!). 
JNPG delivers!

Second.
Graphics. TGC has some nice features like shores on water, but all courses look 'the same' in a kind, where in JNPG the courses looks more different and real. (links, parkland, desert even sci-fi space course as download).

Third.
But as now, TGC is still the more finished game.
JNPG still has only one avatar, no über-detailed stats for every hole, no  seasons, crowds etc.

But.
I defenitely like JNPG more, because there is more 'depth'. But it needs more polish. Till now only the core is superb. Needs more gewgaw to be supreme.

I think this will come sooner or later.

Reviews babbling about exorbitant season-pass are wrong.
Only 250$+ when you want to let it run on a screen-simulator with real clubs (fwhich you could charge, if you DON'T just install it in your living room, - which is the norm. 
But no extra cost, when you want it only play on your own on this steam account. 
But even otherwise it would be convenient.

Last.
This game is REALLY loved by all these Ami-Grandpas.
So I think it is doing something REALLY right, as far at is concerning GOLF-Simulation.
(Who would argue about Golf with ... Amis?  - Maybe Scots...) 

What ever.
This is the best PC Golf game now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052712942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1538793774}
review:
Update: Even with a new machine and renewed attitude, this game still sucks a big pair of Golden Bear nuts.

This game is so realistic, it will make you rather play the real thing than stumble through this confusing "reality" rich pre-pre-alpha.

I've tried to give this game several chances, but upon playing the latest build of the game I give up, for now.

I'll probably be back after a few updates, but to the average or casual gamer, this is not the game you're looking for.

Inexplicable crashes, buggy graphics, and only ONE character model (which is hideously ugly) make this feel like a rushed, empty shell of a game waiting for content. A visit to the poorly designed and buggy developer website only made me feel like this game doesn't have a future.

Micro-transactions seem to be the ultimate goal here with their confusing "Season Pass" and one ball that you can buy. I'm not spending anymore money to think I'm helping make an unplayable game more playable. I've experimented with all swing styles presented in the game, and again, without taking the time to suffer through the learning curve (putting is the worst) you will never feel you've gotten anything out of this game.

This is more of a "reality golf simulator" than a golf video game. The reason successful sports games become successful is they often find engaging ways to make the player feel they are doing better, or making an impossible shot possible.

I'm sure someone will get on me that "THIS GAME ISN'T FINISHED" and to give it a chance later (which I will) this is more of a shining example of reasons we as a community should stop this wave of pre-alpha games from mudding up and getting mixed in with finished games. Since when did unfinished products get a green light to be rushed to consumers? Basically you are paying to test an un-fun real life golf simulation. I'd rather just go play golf, it has fresh air, exercise and sexy beer cart girls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062232099', 'num_games_owned': 5821, 'num_reviews': 291, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1463471297}
review:
Jack Nicklaus Perfect Golf features, to borrow words from one of their devs/fanboys, quite possibly the worst communicated season/annual pass and microtransaction systems that I've ever seen.

Not once on any store front or this very page on Steam is it explained that the season pass is NOT for the majority of Steam gamers even though this is very clearly a Steam game. Players who enjoy the game and would consider the season pass on the basis that they want the next twelve months worth of content (an annual basis) are left to make the decision to pump $200-ish into the game without any knowledge that they wont get any benefit from it.

Steam users have become accustomed to purchasing season passes to their games that are detailed and communicated professionally to the point that that they know what they are going to receive for their money before purchase. They are not thrown into the deep end and face a high priced annual pass that they have little to no way of knowing what they are getting let alone whether the investment is the right one for them -- which it really isn't going to be for a significant percentage of your Steam player base. For those that do fit the bill, you're right, it is a bit of a bargain (ELI5 - other golfing simulation software that serves a very niche audience are generally priced in the vicinity of $1000+ and occasionally upwards of five times that so in effect the devs have made the market much more accessible). 

Although I have had positive communication with ONE member of your team the others that have contacted me along with your fanboys have been quite aggressive. This aggressiveness has reached the point of almost being considered criminally abusive. I have personally elected not to respond in kind. In fact, I argue that silence in this instance is the appropriate response. 

PERFECT PARALLEL, Your game may be one of the most playable golf sims on the market but your behavior and inexcusably woeful communication abilities are the overriding reason why the game suffers such a mediocre review score on Steam. Perhaps if you improved your communication skills your player base would have a much better idea - anything is better than none - of what they are actually criticizing you for. There's a reason why all but one of the most 'helpful' reviews of your game on the front page, as of writing, are thumbs down.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970489771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7385, 'last_played': 1502574059}
review:
I bought this game since Day 1 and have yet to comment on it. I've played probably over 125 rounds, maybe more.  I will recommend this game based on the fact there is nothing else out on the current market like it.  

First of all Links 2003 had set the standard for PC golf back in the day.  Best sim with the most user created free courses and game functionality.  Not many bigger title golf games have really come out since then.  That being said, this game does a couple of things better than the predecessor, but is still missing the mark in some key areas.

Pros:

- Beautiful Graphics (obviously better than Links 2003)
- Nice simulation physics
- Realistic environment sounds
- Good amount of courses for the new user
- UI pretty simple to figure out
- Multiplayer and Private Matches work well
- UIpcoming User Created Course Library starting to grow

MIsses

- No commentary? Doesn't have to be a celeb.  Game feels a tad lifeless without it
- Sound file sharing - Ok I am going to be nit picky but you should have the ability to play sound files during your game whether it be in a window(snap cam) or some other way. This was one of the best features of Links that should be standardized in every golf game.
- The settings to go up and down on your shots doesn't affect the ball hardly at all.
- Some default options missing
  - Why is it every time I want to see the overhead view snap cam I have to click the button? Why can't I check a setting to leave it on? Or have the button clicked deafult to that until it's clicked off.
  - Default view of a friend playing is at an angle. I understand you can move the view around manually every time but why cannot there not be a setting to default that view to straight on like your own shot?
- $5 for an expansion course? (Bethesda)

Overall I am still enjoying and playing this game.  All of my default option gripes probably wouldn't be that big of a deal to fix. The commentary I am sure could be a lot more complicated.  At the end of the day, this is a beautiful modern fun golf sim that doesn't quite have the functionality as it's long ago predecessors.

review:
The most interesting golf game I have ever played and my experience goes back to the beginning of Apple, then PC games.
The graphics are stunning. The ability to play the game at a beginner level and then add complexity as personal skill and mastery of the game increases should keep interest up for a very long time. The fact that many courses are available now (some bundled with the game, one to purchase at this time, many on line by independent designers) is a further benefit for this game. I await the arrival of the Course Forge so I design some of my own courses. 
Some of the earlier reviews mention minor glitches in the basic game and in some of the add on courses. It seems that community comments about the problems bring about speedy updates. IMHO some of the glitches make the game more interesting if one keeps one's sense of humor. As an example, one course manifests a problem with the water hazzard which requires either learning how to play the bounce off the frozen surface or how safe is it to stand on the frozen surface while chipping back to the fairway. I  kind of hope they don't fix that one!
This game is a definite thumbs up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202260672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 173566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3437, 'playtime_at_review': 28597, 'last_played': 1712369122}
review:
I wish I could recommend the game overall - I'm very conflicted about it.
The graphics are so old and basic looking - Looks ok from a distance, but when you're playing it's very poor.

The actual golf game play is probably the best of all options right now if you focus solely on the swing options, physics, ball spin, wind impacts and so forth.  Also, a multiplayer lobby and a multitude of game modes are great to see, but sadly no career mode or "pro mode" or anything like that.

But there also are endless strange bugs and interface weirdness, especially using a controller (which is the newest way to play, so hopefully that gets worked on more).

The main hangup is the old looking graphics.  The game has no grass, really basic looking water, trees with an odd sort of sheen look to them (something weird about how they look especially in the distance) and overall just appears to my gaming eyes like something you might have thought "looked great" in the early to mid 2000's.  Now I'm used to such a higher bar of quality in most every other game, genre and platform, that it is really hard to look at and enjoy for me.  It's all just flat textures draped all over for the most part.  Thumbs down on that for sure.

I guess if you can get past the really old looking graphics, it's a great game of golf. But for me I can not do a "recommend" on it with graphics this behind the times.  Being on a golf course involves natural beauty and graphics quality is a main part of this type of games' appeal to me....and perfect golf lacks in this area big time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972321513', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4738, 'last_played': 1493328405}
review:
Jack Nicklaus Perfect Golf is what you play if you're looking for a realistic and challenging golf sim. This is the real deal.

The game can be as hard as you want it to be. Want to go easy on a flat green course using 3 point click on Beginner? Go for it. After a while, you'll birdie too often and want more of a challenge. No problem. There's Hacker, Amateur, Tour, and Tour Pro that'll challenge you further. These higher difficulties make swing timings more precise, resulting in shots more prone to shank if you're off just a bit. At the highest levels, you won't even be told the wind speed or direction and will have to rely on visual cues like the flag's movement. This says nothing of additional round settings like wind speeds (which can be set to weather forecasts), pin placements, green firmness, etc. You'll botch plenty of shots at first until you practice to get your swing down while you learn to master both courses and conditions. Just like in real golf.

Beyond that, there are different swing styles that change ball striking experience. Want to feel like you're actually swinging something on your PC without a gamepad? Motion Swing allows you to use your mouse as a club to swing. You'll have to literally swing back and forward both straight and within a backswing-to-forwardswing time frame ratio in order to hit your shot straight. If you have a controller, you can use joysticks. 

This is a game with a great deal of depth and multiplayer replayability with a learning curve as steep as you make it. Still, the game launched a bit prematurely. The multiplayer lobby is quirky, at best; dysfunctional, at worst. Computer opponents are wildly inconsistent, too, so to play a decent opponent, you'll have to put up with the lobby's quirkiness or practice on your own.

In spite of all of this, if you're pleased enough with the gameplay, you'll be patient in waiting for patches to remedy the game's weaknesses.

There are negative reviews about season passes that are misinformed. These passes are for additional equipment you can buy to actually hit golf balls into a net and track their flight in-game, which seems like a pretty dang cool add-on if you ask me. The developers are in no way forcing customers to pay for the base game and a season pass to play for a year.

The store also offers additional courses to purchase—currently Bethesda for $4.99. There is unwarranted outcry about this as well because the game comes bundled with plenty of courses to keep the gameplay varied enough for a good while—14 full courses if my count is right, and 2 practice ranges. Offering additional DLC content to the core game is exactly what a lot of developers do these days. It's not in the base game, so therefore, you pay more for it. Sounds fair enough.

All in all, the strengths far outweigh the weaknesses. I do hope the developers continue to flesh out the kinks, but they've managed to produce a very solid game with gameplay that'll keep you coming back for more if the sort of golf sim you're looking for is both realistic and increasingly challenging. These two strengths make the game that much more rewarding and fun when you do get a handle on things and are able to be competitive against others in multiplayer matches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167417641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1678063329}
review:
They have a long ways to go with this game. The lower I set the AI's abilities his shots just get better and better. With all ability settings on the lowest value ("1") he repeatedly drives within feet of the hole. With the greens settings at "easy" the undulation of the turf reminds one of the swells on the Bering Sea--with radical pitches and slopes. On some holes you might think you were playing mini-golf because the cup actually sits atop a mound. The AI makes improbable shots from the tee, from the fairways, and on the greens. To be fair the AI shots are sometimes what you would expect at a setting of "1"--but then there's those "wow" shots. Very inconsistent. 
Also, there is no way to "save" your preferred settings from one session to the next. Each play time requires that you re-set everything to your preferences. 
Also, some graphics are below "par" (pardon the pun). I cringe everytime I look at the deformed wrists of the avatars. It looks painful!
On the positive side, the scenery is very pleasant.
I won't play this game for a month or so. Maybe there will be some significant improvements by then?
I will recommend this game based on the chance that the short-comings may get fixed.

--------------------------------

UPDATE: PC games should be fun even if they are challenging. This game is NOT fun. It is NOT relaxing NOR can it be enjoyed! If you want FRUSTRATION then this is your game. Nothing has improved. The inconsistencies are the only constant. Hit a shot ahead of the "dead center" line and watch your ball slice wildly! Your best guess as to how to make your putt will never be correct. The "easiest" settings are NOT easy. If you want to be AGGRAVATED buy this game. Do NOT believe the PC Gaming review. If this game is still in development why are they charging $34.95!? I'm terrible at real golf and I have allergies that are exacerbated by grass on the fairways and greens; but still real golf is less frustrating and a lot more fun than this game. At least in real golf I know that everytime I hit the ball it's gonna go right!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993543596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 9013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7390, 'last_played': 1600750276}
review:
Now that the game is fully released i can give a full review

Graphics - 6/10 by modern standards the graphics are quite poor, they chose to use directX 9 along with unity, The Graphics look ok at first but when you look closer you realise how basic they are.  Water looks terrible, no 3d grass for light rough and rough, lighting is very basic and the performance is inconsistant from course to course. I have to turn settings down on an I7 4790k@4.6ghz and a amd Fury to maintain 60fps on some courses.

Gameplay - 7/10 RTS is broken, it is way too sensitive, move the mouse back 2 pixels and thats a full back swing at 800dpi* on a 1080p screen, only increasing the screen to 1440p and the mouse DPI down to 400 is the RTS some what controlable,this is using the lowest sensitivity setting in game....

Even then there is no feel and putting is a joke, with the ball rocketing off the face after the smallest slowest movement you can possibly do with a mouse, to top this the game gives zero feedback whilst on the course has to what you are doing right or wrong, the only way to get feedback is to go to the practice area (no putting green btw), and you will get feedback through a launch monitor,  not that it will be any use to you as there is zero explination of what the numbers mean, so if you have never been on launch monitor in real life and had the number explained to you, you are screwed basically. This wasn't thought through at all and they listened to totally the wrong people when implementing this.

*Mice used Roccat Kone XTD and Corsair Vengence M65

However mouse swing using the meter isn't bad at all,  although it will be very difficult for the beginner. so max assists is recommended..

Presention - 6/10 simple menus very easy to navigate....nothing to write home about 

Value - 5/10 Thought long and hard about this, if the game was £14.99 i would say yes the game is good value for what you get, but they have released it at £26.99...and on top of that have release an extra course as day one DLC (if you have DLC ready for day one, it should be in the game at no extra cost) and are planning more micro transactions.  So id say this game isn't good value, as of now there is no career or progression system, there is a planned course designer, but has yet to materialise (no idea what its going to be like)...there is online play, and solo rounds, for a golf enthusiast maybe just enough, but for a gamer looking for something to play, £26.99 is going to be poor value.

Overall 5/10 This game offers nothing for the causual/gamer player, the learning curve is very steep, with zero understandable feedback from the game ( A launch monitor is jibberish to the none enthusiast Golfer, even to some Serious golfers), The gameplay is kind of there, you just have to put is stupid amounts of hours to find it, and you will have to go on the forums to find out what the numbers on launch monitor mean....

I do like parts of this game, but i can not recommend it (not at £26.99), so its a thumbs down from me.

Edit... I was banned from the forums for critizing thier micro transactions implementation in this game, the game is on its way to pay to win, with being able to buy balls and clubs that change the way the game plays.....Avoid this game and do not support this GREEDY developer.

Edit... author: {'steamid': '76561198007300752', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 3023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2270, 'last_played': 1682732866}
review:
EDIT: Review changed in 9/16 to reflect a lack of progress in providing features that were supposed to be in the release. Specifically, the course designer for PG has been long discussed and was supposed to be in the game on release. 4 months later it's still not there. Beyond the course designer, there still is no career mode. The game still has performance issues. There still is limited character customization, no announcers, very limited stats, poor UI, etc. Essentially almost NONE of the negatives have been fixed even though many of those things have been promised. Thus I can't recommend the game because I don't see tangible progress in improving the product. 

-----

I've been arounds since PG's failed kickstarter. I bought the game as soon as it came out on Early Access. However, that doesn't make me a fan. It makes me a fan of golf games. PG does some things right. It does some things wrong. Because it's a mixed bag, it's easier to list what is good and what's bad about it. As always, YMMV.

Pros:
- numerous swing type options - there are multiple though I'm a three clicker all the way and very impressed by the smoothness of the meter. The mouse swing is challenging. They've tried to implement no-cheating modes but they broke the mouse swing while doing so.

- various levels of challenge - play this with all the aids on and you'll be in birdie city. Play this without them and you might be lucky to break 90. I'm not nearly as good as I once was, but at one point I was in the top 10 on Case's Ladder on Links and #1 on another ladder. So I'm glad it's challenging rather than the "Shoot 48 at Augusta on Tiger Woods" mode.

- good physics - I'm still not happy with the backspin but generally the physics are good and better than any other golf game. Backspin still is off and I generate more backspin on my short irons (and I shoot in the 90s) than my avatar in this game. Other than that they're spot on. For instance, if you play a course at higher elevation the ball will travel further. That's a nice touch.

- weather / time of day settings can add some real challenge to your game. I think the wind feels spot-on.

- many different courses to choose from and quite a few to download

- multiple modes of gameplay, including solo, multiplayer and tournaments with match play, team play, alt shot, etc.

- no micro-transactions that improve your game

- no stupid characters that drive the ball 400 yards. Over-driving distance ruins so many golf games and they've prevented that here.



Cons:
- no career mode built into the game yet

- course designer hasn't been released yet (it's now 4 months late and counting)

- I don't like the way the skies look and the trees can look a little jagged

- limited current player animations (no lefties, no females yet though they're coming)

- very,very, very limited character customization

- it requires a decent computer and user made courses don't always run well. In fact, the user made courses often exceed the RAM allowance in the game causing major problems from a chunky swing meter to crashing.

- slightly too limited shot shaping options. I wish I could position my swing path and feet differently to get inventive when shotmaking. 

- very limited stats

- no announcer and limited sound effects

- no Steam Workshop integration (a cardinal sin for a game with downloadable courses)

- really poor and frankly butt-ugly user interface when you enter the game (though it's fine when actually playing a round)


So it's up to you whether to buy it. I can tell you it's a better game than that "other" golf game on Steam and probably the best one available on the market today. But it's by no means perfect yet (pun intended) and while I had hoped that many of the cons would be fixed, this doesn't seem to be happening. The product feels more and more abandoned with a lack of substantial progress since release. 

If you want a golf game now, this is the one to buy becuase frankly it's probably your only decent choice. Since I'm a fan of the old Links games and golf games in general so I continue to load up PG from time to time. But if you aren't a golf nut, this game isn't for you because it's just too limited in the features and progress to appeal to a wider audience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008433123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1462399307}
review:
I got this game for free as a birthday gift because I have been a fan of games like Mario Golf Toadstool Tour. It was a fantastic game in the pre-release and the core gameplay still stands. However, as soon as the end product was released the name "Perfect Golf" was changed to "Jack Nicklaus Perfect Golf" and micro transactions were added. This seems to range from little things like shirts and pants for your character to golf courses. The prices for this adds up to $250 a year for a season pass?

This game was originally $19.99 before release and now stands at $34.99. I was thinking $20 was too much... this is abysmal. A game developer cannot simply add a $250 microtransactions to a game (PER YEAR?!?) and price the game as $34.99. This is unacceptable. Total cash grab. I cannot believe my eyes.

If this game were to get rid of it's microtransactions and put the price down to about $15 I would recommend it. However, as the current price stands, it is simply not worth the money.

Perfect Golf is a well developed golf simulator that does a good job in multiplay and allows user made course to be downloaded and played in the game lobby which increases its customer value. I bought the game in Beta for $14.99 and it was and is well worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271693262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1840, 'last_played': 1488182966}
review:
This is my review of the finished game and not the early access version
I have to change my initial review as the core content on the game remains unchanged.
Esssentially this a lifeless game without any atmosphere or real point to it.
It reminds me of golf games from long ago on PC. Games like links and then the Arnold Palmer games were lifeless slogs around beautifully rendered(for their time) courses.
This game has no career mode, virtually no tournaments and liitle point to playing it
The few tournaments that exist are run via an external forum and you only play if you fullfil their unreasonably strict criteria. As is the norm with forums, the adminstrators control everything. 
I have given up even bothering to enter them as its such a conveluted process.

Its rather sad that this is another game left to wallow in such a poor state.

If you want a good game of golf via PC then look elsewhere
If suffer from insomnia and need a good nights sleep, then I recommend playing this game just before going to bed.
I never fails to put me to sleep. In fact, i never get to finish a round, its so futile and soporific.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960519852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1532294569}
review:
This isnt a bad game at all. It's a far cry from what I remember PGA to be on xbox(which is what I was hoping this would match up to), but for the most part a good game of golf.

It's tricky to get used to and there are a few basic features which I really feel need to be added. The UI/UX desperatly needs to be improved. For example, the 'select' button could toggle an overlay of controls for a joypad as for me that button was unused and I found myself getting lost in controls.

A strength indicator should be added - % backswing versus % follow through to give a measurement of power as you take the shot, coupled with a visual aid of how straight your follow through was would be great as sometimes you draw/fade when you feel confident your follow through was perfect.

Putting seems to be very random. I found it very hard to get a consistent putt.

Draw/Fade/forward/backspin seem to have very little effect for me, and the roll of a green seems to be a bit un responsive... but this could be because I've only played a couple of hours. 

Not a game I'll play on my own, but very enjoyable in its current state to play with a couple of people you know with voice coms on. I'm really looking forward to this game being further developed - loads of potential! Worth a buy

author: {'steamid': '76561197988532231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1516060907}
review:
Much like real golf, the things that are the most unrelated to golf are what cause the most frustrations.

Happy to change my review later, but as of now the Alphaness of this game is just too frustrating to deal with. I mean, this is golf ... a game who's purpose and intent is to fill one's time with it's own inherent frustrations as a way of rejuvenating one's soul from the frustrations of day-to-day life. If I am frustrated in this game, it should be because the greens are fast and it's especially windy that day, not because my swing suddenly develops some kind of Charles Barkleyesque series of pauses and stutters for some unpredictable reason. That would be a sign that I should see a neurologist. 

Clean up the bugs and make this game run snappy and I'll be back, otherwise, I've paid for your dinner at the Olive Garden, enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979667688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1463532311}
review:
"this is based on not even an hour of gameplay as i have to go to sleep so i can wake up for work which starts in an hour.

Firstly this is quite possibly the best golf game in recent years that i have played certainly better than alot of past titles (im looking at you EA) liking the motion swing and i really like the way the shots just feel right.

The graphics though not amazing are really good, though really what can you do with a golf game graphically without taking away from the whole simulation end of it. I would add though that the course that i played on seemed lifeless, i mean it would be great even in solo play to see some other people or a caddy or something. Also noticed a little bit of jitter on the comet trail when the ball starts to drop after the peak of the shot.

AI is needed for solo play 

The only other bad thing i can think of is the sound design, in florida glades i can hear the ambience track looping. This may not sound like that big of a gripe but once you notice it it becomes infuriating and to have the same sound effect on all 18 holes in the track... well just play it and you will understand. I dont know if this is the same in the other courses but this must be a testament to how good the game is i cant wait to find out cos it is a brilliant game.

Also. this is early access but i couldnt help but notice there is a pro shop... all the values are $0 at the moment but i cant help but wonder if this is going to become a game that ends up cashing in big style after its release. If you can win money during games thats okay but if you are going to be asking $200 for a golf club that absolutely obliterates any competition this game is going to go south fast! 

Other than that early access is good i like it and i will continue to play more of it.. And now im late for work bye"

I was correct on one thing, this game is a cash grab after release, save your money and actually buy a set of golf clubs, trust me its cheaper

review: I'm pretty impressed with this game.  I was looking for a current AAA golf title and was coming up empty.  This delivers at least as much as any golf game I've played, and much more than most.  I'd like to see a more customizeable avatar, some equipment choices, and maybe day length options that go under 12 hours (imagine getting to watch the sun rise as you tee off and watch it set as you pull the pin on 18, but as it stands it's a love-letter to golfers and PC gamers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115865717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4072, 'last_played': 1560335016}
review:
Perfect Golf came as a surprise. Surprise that it was not more expensive and surprise as to the emotions it generated. I have been a golf player for over fifty years, not a good one, probably a bad one, but I enjoyed the challenge of the course and the chat with my playing partner. This is the first simulation that I have ever played that generates all those same emotions. The satisfaction at a great shot, the disbelief when the very next shot takes you into the rough, the failure to understand where it went wrong! It is an amzing simulation. I know the golf angle are sometimes peculiar, especially when stand up hill on a steep incline, I know that recovery from that situation is a lot easier than in real life, but wow! I love it.

Do not wait for the retail version, get in there on early access and start enjoying the experience. It also helps the development as this is just a small indie operation. Even if it was never developed further I would love it.

The pros:-

Brilliant simulation
Fabulous Graphics
Amazing detail

The cons:-

No stats
Lag when you are not the host in multi player
No course builder (Oh I would love that!)

Well done Perfect Parallel, can wait for the next version

review:
A very realistic golf sim. My Father was having issues reading greens when playing golf, so I bought this sim to see if it would help him at all. On average he puts one less time now than he used to. 

The user created courses are good and more often than not, very good.  Watching divots and sand fly as well as having ballmarks when landing on the greens is just wonderful.  I really enjoy the real time swings. 

Really worth the entry for early access if you like playing golf.

author: {'steamid': '76561198289112054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1310, 'last_played': 1546687908}
review: ok, well ive had the game for about tow weeks now and its the only game i play.  and what i like?  the five difficulty options, adjustable options within the 5 general options including various assist toggles, all of the really well made courses available for download,  about 35 in all with a new one released just today. (wingedfoot). and graphically ive read positive and negative about this game, but i play on high settings, (not ultrahigh) and the graphics are down right beautiful,  better than rory on ps4 and much much better than thegolfclub.    as for the gameplay?  thats the best part,  using a mouse you get the tempo swing of 4:1 mimicing a real golf swing tempo.  and you get a practice range to sort this out with feedback to tell you how far off base you were with the tempo, if you struck the ball on the heal or toe of the club ,  (which meant you swing path wasnt totally true). all effecting the result.  it is SO NICE to have a golf game made for the true golfer. this game really feels like your faced with a challege on every shot , just like in real golf.  of course if you dont want that you can choose beginner setting and have an easier go at it.  there are online tours and tournaments , and from what ive read the devs are working on inplementing a true career mode that they say they want to be really good before releasing.  unlike some other games career mode which was obviously just thrown together.  new course coming, plenty to play now, excellent challenge,  what else could a golfer want in a golf game?   thanks for this great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972732705', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 107046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9636, 'last_played': 1680728184}
review:
The game is still in early access, it is not yet in its final state. However, I have played PC Golf games from LEaderBoard to Jack Nick, to Links. I played Links until last year. I am now playing Perfect Golf almost everyday.
I do not play golf IRL so I can not speak with any authority on how closely the game matches real world play. I can say I enjoy playing the game and it feels like realistic physics. I play 3 Click  swings, but mouse and controller support is available. ONline multi-player is supported, but I only play solo.  User created courses are becoming available and 3rd party sites are beginning to offer tournaments and ladders.  Computer players are available (some work left for tuning).

Again Early access, but VERY playable and enjoyable as it is. IMHO most of the major features are in place even if not yet perfect. My biggest wishlist woudl be accumulated stats (they are available for each round played) and a career/season feature.

review:
I hated this game half a year ago, it was too slow and imprecise, requiring too much fiddling to get the shots right. I tried it again today, and it was just down right beautiful and pleasurable. The developers have done lots of improvements. The graphics rendered smoothly, the precision for power/direction gauge was perfect, and many golf swing settings automatically set up for you, such as the splash shot out of a greenside bunker.

This suddenly became the best golf game I have played :-).

author: {'steamid': '76561198030042376', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 76859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6, 'playtime_at_review': 17489, 'last_played': 1711812400}
review:
This is my first reveiw of any game of any kind. I normally just don't do it.
The reason i have taken pen to paper (kind of) is to explain how wonderful this game is. People have commented on how good value for money this game is but it is so much more than that. This is the best, most immersive game of golf on any platform anywhere. I have played PS4 games of golf, other PC games and none of them compare to the qualities that this game has. I am pleased that i was on board from day one and have supported this game from the beginning as it has turned out to be a truly wonderful game. 
We are still in the very early stages of this game with so much more to come but the highest recommendation i can give this game is, if it was left where it is today i would still play on it each and every day. It is that good. 
If you love playing golf, whether alone or with a group of friends or a bigger community, then look no further. If you enjoyed the old style links then this is its bigger beautiful sister..with all the bells and whistles on it that we could have only dreamed about back in the day.
I cannot recommend this game highly enough. With the soon to be released 'Course Forge' (course creator) and a multitude of courses being released by skillful, talented designers...the future is bright for Perfect Golf.....
Don't miss out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175358535', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 51067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23790, 'last_played': 1624199021}
review:
I have played just about every golf game that has been created.  I am not one of those that thinks there can only be ONE good golf game.  I think there is room for multiple games and that all can thrive.  
I think of all the online golf options at the moment, PG has the most options and will appeal to the most people.
You can use multiple swing methods as of the last update and each swing type has multiple skill levels incorporated.
You can customize PG to be as easy or as hard as you like.  You can play different difficulty levels in the same game which is great because my friends and I don't all like the same swing type or difficulty.
I am pretty sure you can also set games up where you can play from different tees which is great for setting up games between PC and sim players with real clubs.  
Like I said, I have played them all and even though PG is still not officially released, IMO it is the best option out there at the moment for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103370075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7462, 'last_played': 1542605173}
review:
I have been waiting for a golf sim, and the early access of Perfect Golf seems to be headed in the right direction. Obviously, with an early access, there are things that are needed and things that are fine as is. So far, I can say confidently that the heart is beating in this game. Visually it's appealing and the game-play engine itself is a good start. Some of the issues at this point, I hesitate to mention, again because I suspect every feature and tweak I would like to see has been accounted for by the developers and they are working on it. That being said: 

The menus need work and making changes to the settings on the fly is clunky. The types of shots are limited at the moment and needs attention, as does the power meter and putting helpers. Right now, they don't really make much sense and seem arbitrary. There's no way to punch shots through or accurately alter spin the way the real game allows. The power meters and putting grids also are somewhat of a mystery and don't seem to be designed to let the player really know exact measurements. This may be on purpose, but still this is a sim and not real life, so we need some way to benchmark our swings and fades, etc...

 It needs a player history system so I can go back and review my previous rounds, and of course, it needs more courses. I hope most of all, the developers are going to be able to make a deal with the PGA for rights to their courses and tournament play, but even if it remains simply a non-PGA golf simulation, that's fine on its own. If you want to learn the game and progress without getting bored, I think this will be a good title someday. I hope it is sooner than later.

added: May 5, 2016: 
Now that the supposed general release has been pushed out, I felt I need to comment further on this game. As I said in my earlier review, the heart of a good game was there, and I was hoping Perfect Parrellel was working hard on the serious issues in the engine. Apparently, they are working harder on the marketing and getting Jack Nicklaus to put his name on a game that is FAR, FAR from finished. 

I'm wondering if the makers of this game couldn't care less about the gamers in Steam and are more interested in the Golf Simulators out there than can use this software. Because right now, us gamers are getting no love from the game. 

A few points for the developers, which I hope read this: 

...The putting mechinism is simply awful. Damn near unplayable. It's swing mechanics are inconsistent and clunky. There is no context to the power of the swing and they give little to no credible way to read the greens. It needs serious re-tooling before this game can be considered top notch. 

...there is no way to craft shots and the chipping and pitching is abysmal and inconsitent. You'll never hit the same shot twice in the same conditions. 

...the swing meter, which is the only way most gamers are going to play this game, is baffling and inconsistent. it gives no power context either but even if it did, you can never re-create shots no matter how hard you try. 

I'm holding out hope this will improve, but if this is now considered a released game, I'm not holding my breath that major changes to the engine are coming.

updated: June 17

...a few of the patches and fixes are helping on some of the issues I pointed out in May. Putting seems to have normalized somewhat. It's getting better about giving enough clues to read a green. Still, I think the grid needs to be smaller squares and the BLI is a little clunky, but better. 

...still though, chipping and pitching are so frustrating. Practice is one thing, but inconsistency in the UI and the game engine is something else. Pitching and chipping still is a nightmare of randomness. Random in that you never ever know how your chip or pitch is going to react in any situation. it's impossible to recreate a shot that has the same variables and the engine will flatout fail you by over shooting or undershooting even though the power, lie and variables might be the same. NEEDS ATTENTION NOW.

...crafting shots is still a major problem. the shot maker function just doesn't work for lowering or raising your trajectory. It works left and right, but not up and down. 

...still worth it, as this is a simulation and not an arcade, ,and as long as they don't morph into a pay to win model, I will continue to recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147921501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1647251161}
review:
I've been looking for a golf game along the lines of the old Links for a long time, Perfect Golf is it. 

For an early access game it's quite polished already and the course selection out of the box is good. Course Forge and user created courses... I can't wait! The 3 point click system works well, the draw/fade controls are very impressive. The hole map is good showing where your shots should be landing for par. 

On the down side, the biggest deffiency I've found is the post-shot screen... It'll tell me how far I've hit it, how far to the flag but it doesn't tell me where the ball is laying, fairway, green, sand, rough etc. I can only find out by watching one of the replay options (which are awesome btw!), sometimes I just want to get on with it. 

There's also some work to be done on long distance rendering of the ball, not a big deal though. On rare occassions I can also set the aim marker but the player doesn't re-adjust, like I said it's rare and for an early access game the occassinal quirk is expected. 

I'm very pleased with perfect Golf, I should be going to bed but I might sneak in another round!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992830044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 42554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18031, 'last_played': 1631376893}
review:
In my opinion this is the best golf game available. I own others but now only play this one. The big difference for me is the swing mechanic. On the higher difficulty settings the real-time-swing actually requires a skilled effort at the swing. Other games I have played recently (such as TGC) are OK but the swing on those just seems so easy - also like you go on auto-pilot when swinging - and gets a little boring. Not so with Perfect Golf as you need to pay attention to your swing.

I also like that the physics of the game determine where the ball ends up - it is not predetermined as some other games are.

Graphics are decent as well, but I don't have a high end video card and so cannot comment much on that aspect. All I can say is that it is comparable to other recent PC golf titles I have played.

As for the number and variety of courses, it is getting better now with more user-designed courses being released.  In my opinion the variety and quality of courses is what is important rather than sheer numbers. Currently, even in early access, I see variety of courses in Perfect Golf getting better and better. They are quality tracks with a good range of difficulties available.  As the Perfect Golf course designing community grows there will be even more courses of varying visual styles getting released on top of an already great set of courses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080722311', 'num_games_owned': 9, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 245255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23267, 'last_played': 1695643264}
review:
I have been playing Tiger Woods '08 PC on a regular basis since it came out back in 2007.  No modern golf game has come close.  That is until PerfectGolf was released.  

The graphics are top notch and very realistic.  You can see all of the undulations and slopes on the fairways/greens very clearly unlike some golf games.  The addition of trees and bushes from SpeedTree last year improved the visuals a great deal.  The graphic improvements will no doubt continue in the future with the possible addition of 3D blades of grass using Nvidia’s Turf Effects tool.

The newly implemented Real Time Swing for controller and mouse has enhanced the game immeasurably in addition to the availability to download fine user made courses (around 24 available as of the date of this review).  That brings the current number of stock and user made courses up to around 37, a number no other modern golf game can touch.  These course numbers will continue to grow and grow once the CourseForge tool comes out and also once the developers start making licensed courses available.  

Online play is great with turn based multiplayer and the ability to tee off with up to 8 players.  You can stop and resume your round at a later time.  There are loads of different play modes available in PerfectGolf.  If tournaments are your thing you can participate in many online as well as ones on onlinegolftour.net.  The game also has a cool replay feature that allows you to watch the last shot from a number of different angles.  Your opponent(s) can see the replays as well.

Another big plus for PerfectGolf is the freecam mode which allows you to more effectively read putts and scope out your next shot, even while your online opponent is getting ready to hit.  Take a virtual tour of the entire course from every conceivable angle and soak in the wonderful immersion that this game provides.

PerfectGolf has lived up to its potential as superb golf simulation.  Every update over the last year has shown improvement, especially the most recent update from last month.  This community driven game will only get better in the months and years to come.  Be sure to give it a try and you won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992682505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 153751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28758, 'last_played': 1694222690}
review:
With the advent of the Real Time Swing control interfaces, Perfect Golf has established itself as a major player in the golf game market.  It was already a solid performer with its 3-click and Motion Swing (mouse) swing interfaces. but the all new Real Time Swing - Mouse (RTS-Ml) and Real Time Swing - Controller (RTS-C) broadens the appeal of the game by more dynamically engaging the senses in a live process.

Both RTS-C and RTS-M require a sensual mastery over an analog control mechanism that has a reasonable and rewarding learning curve.  There are also 5 levels of difficulty to help you wade into the world of real time swing interfaces at a level suited to any skill set.  I've been a real time swing controller fan since Links 2004 on the original XBox, and Perfect Golf's RTS-C has finally taken a controller swing interface through the portal that Links 2004's opened and added dimensions to its performance that uncannily model the nuances of a golf swing in a manner I wouldn't have ever dreamed would be possible with a controller.

 I'm a slightly better than average skill player, and I've managed to break par only 3 times in 50+ rounds, using "Hacker" difficulty (the scale runs Beginner, Hacker, Amateur, Pro, Tour Pro) with my XBox 360 wired controller.  Some would say that someone who's used to shooting 62 - 66 in a computer golf game would be frustrated by this.  Au contraire, I find it stimulating to be challenged to fully think out and execute every shot.  A fairway or green in regulation is something you don't take for granted with RTS-C.  What keeps me going is I am seeing a gradual improvement in my game as I become more familiar with the intricately scaled analog interace the game uses.  I'm probably only a few weeks away from stepping up to Amateur!

Perfect Golf has so much more to offer besides its cutting edge interface options.  Its course creation suite called "Course Forge" has already given birth to a couple dozen user created courses, many of which are commercial quality.  RobC's Bandon Dunes is as good as any of the stock courses that come with the game.  PG also has a bevy of multiplayer options in its Multiplayer Lobby, in addition to having an ongoing chat room from which you can discuss the game and learn from others.  There's also a facility to support user created tournaments that is proving to be popular with community sites like OnlineGolfTour.net, which hosts a number of Tours and Tournaments of various difficulty and control types, in addition to reviewing and hosting downloadable, user created courses.

Keep in mind that Perfect Golf is still in Early Access and is still being refined.  It's highly playable in its current form, but it's also interesting to see the degree of enhancements this game is getting in these final stages.  The developers are also open to user input in these final stages of the game's birth so feel free to sign up at PerfectParallel.com and weigh in with your opinions, experiences, and suggestions.   Whether you're a casual player or a die-hard sim-head, You're not going to find a better value for $19.99!

author: {'steamid': '76561198207191504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 328447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 695, 'playtime_at_review': 39504, 'last_played': 1712321616}
review:
The key to deciding whether you should buy this game is whether you like golf.  Real life golf is frustrating, but very rewarding if you can achieve success, and to do that, it takes some work.  This game is the same way, you have to put some time in to get some success - but it can be fun on the way due to the high quality courses available upon which to play.  I have been pleasantly surprised by the quailty of the courses, both the ones supplied by default in the game, and the user designed courses which so far have proven to be of as high a quality as the default courses.
My favorite method of play (swing type) is the newly implemented Real Time Swing - Motion Swing which is proving to be very immersive giving you the feeling that you are really on a golf course and not sitting in front of a computer.
Some of the new courses and swing type changes is stirring more interest in this game and there is quite a community of active players who hang out in the lobby for online multiplayer games.  There is also a site which offers weekly tournaments seemlessly integrated into the game with nearly 100 players signed up at the tour pro level (the one I play).  I do not know how many play in the other level tournaments, I suspect that it is 100s more.  There are currently no additional costs to fully participate in the game, courses, lobby or tournaments (although the tournament host does solicit donations on the website through a button).  Eventually there will be premium content for purchase (licensed courses, and accesories which will only be cosmetic and not give you an advantage in the game), but that content will not be necessary to enjoy the game.
There will be a program called course forge which will allow anyone who purchases this game to design beautiful course the same way that the original ones were developed.  The current crop of user developed courses were designed by beta testers of course forge.  Course forge will come out when the game exits Early Access, probably sometime this year (but don't quote me).

Pluses - gameplay is rich, not repetitive, due to realistic physics and variability
              interest in the game is growing, lots of partners/opponents available
              developer is active, listens to gamers suggestions and incorporates improvements
              game works on multiple platforms including golf simulators

Minuses - game requires modern computer graphics power to enjoy smooth gameplay
                 players who want instant gratification may be disappointed with learning curve

My advice is to purchase this game while it is still in Early Access as it will surely be more than $20 when it is fully released.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150891244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 113268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19423, 'last_played': 1668544584}
review:
Highly recommended.  A recent update added quite a few community made courses (along with updates to the stock courses in the game) and also added several new swing styles. 

A wide range of swing styles are available:

Traditional 3-click with a power meter

Motion Swing with the mouse that has a meter on the screen (your choice of swinging horizontally or vertically)

Real Time Swing with the mouse (your choice of swinging horizontally or vertically.  No meter on the screen but the player animation moves in concert with the mouse movement) 

Real Time Swing with a controller 

The game can also be played on a home golf simulator.  



The motion swings are my personal favorites.  Tempo has a large part in determining the outcome of the shot (as well as swing path and heel/toe hits)  so it's not as simple as straight back/straight through.  A truly wonderful way to play PC golf.  


There are also a wide range of difficulty options so you can jump right in and enjoy the game.  The easier levels are a great introduction to the game.  Casual player or just want to have a fun round?  It's here.  
   
The highest levels of difficulty are quite tough but it doesn't feel unfair or gimmicky.  If you can control your swing, you can still score well.  If you're not playing well, it can be a real grind, but  it is so rewarding when you put a good swing on the ball.  A great option for the hardcore sim player. 

The course designs are beautiful and the ball physics are the best I've seen in a PC golf game.  A wide range of stimp settings are available for the green speeds, several firmness settings for the fairways, and several settings for pin positions.    

Currently there are about 33 courses in the game, as well as a large driving range and a short game practice area. 

 
The game is still in Early Access so things are still being worked on.  Things not yet included in the game but are planned for the future:

-Career mode

-Assortments of clothing/animations/clubheads/balls/shafts etc... 

-Course building software

-More courses

-Improved AI for the CPU players

-Country clubs and tournaments


There currently is a REALLY good third party tournament site that hosts weekly tournaments for various skill levels as well as fun ancillary events.  

They have an automatic scoring system set up that will keep track of your scores and stats after each round and maintains them on their site.  They also maintain different tours, world rankings, money leaders, ongoing season stats, etc.. and it's free to join.  A very well run tour. 

http://onlinegolftour.net/index.html


I'm sure I'm forgetting some things but again, this is a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198173375345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 26993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5645, 'last_played': 1613275420}
review:
The latest update to this game really shows the potential I was hoping for. The Devs have obviously worked very hard to add so much to the game, Such as new swing methods, including  real time mouse swing and real time controller swing. I think the controller swing will be a big plus to those that have played golf games on xbox  or playstation. Also now available for free are user made courses. While the Course forge has not been released yet to the general public those that were Beta testing it made some courses which you can now download and play in the game. This in itself is a huge step forward and with them being free it should open the doors for many that were a bit hesitant about the game. The life blood in my opinion of a golf game is the ability to add courses and play them for free. I know this was not the direction that  the game first looked at going but PP have listened to the feed back of the community and have changed their mind. This was a game breaker decision for me and probably for many more. The fact that PP listened and heard all the pro's and con's of free user made courses then decided that this is what the community wanted in itself  is not a small thing. How many times with other games have suggestions been made but fall on deaf ears. I can assure you I know of more then one or two. This isn't the only time that PP has listened to the community and either changed something or improved on it. That is huge for instilling confidence as a consumer that they actually do read the forums and not just pay lip service to it. 

When course forge is released to the public the list of courses will grow by a vast margin as many of us will try our hand at designing. Now some will fiddle with it and give up but others will hang in there to try and grasp all the challanges it will bring. Still the thought of getting real terrain data and to be able to create a real course with realistic terrain and elevation has me very excited. I too wondered if it was ever going to see the light of day but with this new update there is no doubt in my mind it will happen. 

So if you want to try a different kind of golf game of one where the devs do  listen to the community (That of course doesn't mean we always get our way but heck at least they take the time to respond and explain why they choose a way of doing something ) Then don't hesitate to get the game. I think in the near future you will see even bigger and better things to come and if you love to play golf games now is the time to get in on the action. Come check it out at the PP forums. Yes there is a lot of different topics to sort through but you may be glad you did. I know I am.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078010478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 67505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26669, 'last_played': 1621868819}
review:
My fellow reviewers have talked already a lot about the wonderful and realistic realtime physics (a real revolutionary and groundbreaking innovation of the golf genre). They have talked about the countless options (everybody will find a setup to his liking). They talked about the renditions of real courses, the four different swing mechanics, the absolute realistic looking graphics and the simlike character of the game.

So i want to tell you a story what all this really means if you are standing on the golf course in Perfect Golf:

I played an online tournament and was standing on the 17th tee at TPC Sawgrass (it is called Florida Glades in the game). I was 2 behind the leader who was already in the clubhouse. Many of you will know the traditional pin position on Sundays. In the corner right of the green only a few yards away from the water. So i needed birdie but the wind was coming hard from the right. To make things worse: my stock shot is a little draw - i developed that in a lot of hours on the practice range - yes, on the practice range. The game is easy to pick up in the lowest difficulty level. But if you want to play at the tour pro level, you have to hit a lot of golf balls on the range to get good enough to beat par.

So, now. I had to make birdie. I had to change my natural movement of the mouse in order to move the ball from left to right against the wind - and i was in between clubs. Should i swing harder to gain a little more length and a lot of spin (yes, the game has this priciple of golf physics in!!) with a higher danger of mishitting the shot? Or should i club up take a partial swing and try to land it a little short (water on 17th!!) and let it run towards the hole?

Decisions, Decisions. Yes, you have to make them in Perfect Golf, like on a real golf course. But you CAN make them, because the game offers every shot you can perform in real life. That is the real immersion of Perfect Golf.

Perfect Golf is playing golf on your screen - it's not playing a video game named golf!

If you don't have it in your library and are a fan of sports games, you simply cannot hesitate! Perfect Golf is by far the best simulation of the game of golf i have ever played - and it is still in early access. There are a lot of things to come.

P.S.: I overcutted my tee shot on the 17th because i had not enough muscle memory for that special shot. Made double bogey and haven't won. Did it matter? No, cause i love this game!

Perfect Golf is the perfect blend of each;  animations and 3D affects that were missing in Links and realistic ball physics that were missing in Tiger Woods.

The amazing thing is that a group of people who were committed to developing a top notch golf simulation came straight from the Links community!  They breathed new life into that franchise, as much as they could make it better, and now their expertise is shining through with this game.

The developers listen to the community, the updates are fulfilled as necessary, the quality continuing to rise with every "change."

The purchase was a no brainer for me.  I'm an average gamer, not as hard core as I was 20+ years ago with the Links franchise, but I find myself venturing down that rabbit hole everytime I fire this beauty up......

Have had limited experience with computer golf games, really only a few years. I began playing WGT on a recommendation from a friend but quickly realized the game was just not what I was looking for. A quick web search brought this game to my attention and I must say it is fascinating, addictive, challenging, frustrating...everything I love about golf IRL. 

The game physics, swing choices, difficulty levels and available courses at this time provide all the entertainment value anyone could ask in an extremely affordable EA package.

The Forums are friendly and extremely informative. What really has my interest is the pending addition of Course Forge where you can try your hand at designing a golf course. I would recommend this game to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134826749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 30523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12820, 'last_played': 1708227779}
review:
In a few words, [b]this is an [i]excellent[/i] computer golf game![/b]  It is quite advanced for an early access title.  The game can be very challenging or more relaxing, depending on what level you choose to play at and what aids you select to help your golfing experience.  I think eveyone can find a method to play to make Perfect Golf one of the most enjoyable golf games you've ever played.  I would [u]highly[/u] recommend this game to all computer golfers!    

What follows in this review is a lengthy discussion of some of the features (not all of them) provided in the game - analogous to the list of options the game provides!

I bought Perfect Golf when it first became avialable in Early Access.  I played the Links series of golf, and played a very small bit with the PGA/TW series.  To me, PG is bit more similar to Links than TW games, but it's not a new version of Links.  The game developments over the first 13 months of early access have come reasonably steadily and each one providing new features and bug fixes of the reported issues.  I have complete faith that this will continue for however long early access continues; with the present state of the game, I suspect it won't be much more than a few more months until release (but that is only my guess).

The game requires surprisingly (to me) high hardware requirements to get the most detail from the game.  The most important thing is you video card.  You really need to have a dedicated video card; an on-board video card will not deliver the experience that players will want, even at the lowest quality settings of the game.  However, lower end systems and middle-of-the-road systems with dedicated video cards can generally run the game reasonably well.

Perfect Golf can be a very difficult golf game - perhaps as difficult as the real game for some.  However, there are many aids that can be employed to make the game more relaxing.  There are currently four options for input methods:
- a "traditional" style 3-click swing meter suing the mouse button
- game controller with thumbstick on the personal computer
- mouse movement, now available in a real-time format, so the golfer swings as you move the mouse
- golf simulator hardware (Trackman 3/4, Foresight GC2, SkyTrack)

The 3C swing uses a round meter which is pretty familiar to most computer golf players.  I believe the 1.3.9.0 update coming in February 2016 will have an option to make the player avatar move as 3C swing meter moves.  I'm not familiar with the controller methods, so I can't comment on this input method.  The mouse movement method allows you to change the direction of movement from vertical to horizontal as well as the sensitivity to allow for various DPI settings in your mouse configuration as well as various resolution settings for the game itself (4K, HD, VGA, etc.).  The mouse swing can optionally be set as a real-time swing.  I also cannot comment on the simulator input, but from what I've read from those fortunate to have simulator hardware, all very much enjoy Perfect Golf.

I really enjoy the challenge of the game using a horizontal mouse swing.  I haven't tried the real-time swing yet, but I definitely will be giving it a go.  I like how you can control the ball movement by making a different path with the mouse, and thus imparting draw/hook spin or fad/slice spin as required for the shot.  The physics of sideslopes, uphill/downhill lies, wind and elevation effects in the game provide the most realistic ball flight I've seen in golf games.  

Courses designed in the Course Forge by users wil become avilable for all players very soon.  The previews of the courses as well as a few that have been released by Perfect Parallel with the game so far have been very good.  I suspect there will be many more coming, but I also suspect they will all of be good quality and not something slapped together in a few minutes or hours.  

There are many modes of play (stroke/medal play, solo/team match play, and others) as well as the option to play online against other live players from around the world.  There are limimted number of official tournaments at this time, but other web sites, such as the Online Golf Tour or OGT, provide a very good complement to Perfect Golf.  I suspect after the game is release, Perfect Parallel will provide more official tournaments, but it's always good to have optiosn with other tournament providers as well!  OGT will also host user-created courses for free download/addition to the game.

One of the few drawbacks in the 1.3.9.0 build of the Perfect Golf may be the lack of a career mode.  Many computer golfers want this, but it won't be provided by Perfect Parallel until after the release of the game.  The ongoing development of the game after release should ensure that a detailed and realistic career mode will be provided, based on the attention to detail and reality that Perfect Parallel have exhibited in the game thus far.  I have no doubt that whatever is eventually provided will be very enjoyable.

Perfect Golf is currently only available on the computer (Windows, Mac, Linux), but Perfect Parallel have indicated it will be ported to XBox One and PS4, although no timetable has been provided.  Again, I strongly recommend Perfect Golf for any computer golf fan.  It's a steal for the price and will likely provide many hours of entertainment!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198278108346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1594415761}
review:
I am a SkyTrak owner, and have been looking at Perfect Golf and The Golf Club for options to play sim golf. Both are soon to be options. I knew of TGC, but had never heard of PG until a few months ago. After playing both, I am leaning strongly towards choosing PG. Here's why. First off, you can play this across many operating systems. You aren't limited to Windows only. Secondly, so far this game is showing strong graphics without requiring the top of the line in hardware. These developers are walking a fine line in that regard and so far winning it. Thirdly, there is already a solid online community for this game, for people looking for casual play or competitve play.

As for the game play itself it is very intuitive for the most part. I did have to look up a few things that aren't immediately evident from just jumping in and playing (like how to change clubs or shot types) but the learning curve is overall low. The courses available now are all top notch with a few real courses in there, and there are a lot in development soon to be released. 

For a game in beta, it feels an awful lot like a mature application. I have not run into any bugs at all really. And the price point is great. You should definitely give it a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134305023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 219300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46015, 'last_played': 1699055166}
review:
Perfect Golf is a great golfing game.  Perfect Golf is not an easy golf game to play.  Do not expect to have below par scores out of the gate.  That will take time and experience because Perfect Golf is more of a golf sim than a video golf game. So it is not a game some gamers will like. 

This game offers five difficulty levels from beginner, to hacker, amateur, pro and the top difficulty level tour pro. 
The game offers 5 different swing types to play consisting of 3 click, vertical or horizontal motion swing, Controller and golf simulator support.  
As of today we have 15 courses to play with more courses still in the pipeline waiting to be released.
I can play individual solo rounds, either offline or online.  I have multiplayer rounds and team multiplayer rounds available to also. 

This game is still in Early Access and getting better with each update.   
 
I get all this for $20.00 USD. Can't beat that.  :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198009330660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 53995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 283, 'playtime_at_review': 8438, 'last_played': 1712366627}
review:
I'm recommending this game for what it is; a lot of others are reviewing it based on what it isn't (yet).

So what is it?  It's a golf sim.  It's targeted at people who want the feel of real golf.  Good physics, accurately rendered real courses, lots of camera options.

The game does lack a lot of features that modern gamers probably expect, career modes, avatar customisation, tee options etc.  But you have to keep in mind it's an indie title.  I'm not sure how big the development team is, but I doubt it's huge.  They've been making steady improvements and constantly provide informative feedback.  Progress has been slow, but the patient have been rewarded and they're getting close to a polished product as I write this.  Even those who have been hammering the developers with criticisms re: the physics are starting to quite down as adjustments are made.

There has been some controversy regarding the direction Perfect Parallel will take regarding a possible subscription service to play user made courses.  I too am concerned, but to give the game a thumbs down based on something that hasn't happened yet is unfair.

Ignore the 6/10 average.  As a fairly cheap Early Access game, it gets an 8 from me.  If you love your golf give it a go, get on the forums and help make it into something magnificent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014359125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 10235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5301, 'last_played': 1661384542}
review:
To start, this is simply the best golf simulator I've come across. There are times when I enjoy it more than the real thing, simply because I score better.

 I do, however, have one major complaint, that being the lack of a full range of practice facilities. In the real world I spend much of my golf time practicing the short game; pitching, chipping, putting and sand traps. Unfortunately all one can really do in PG in the way of practice is go to the range.  I do find aspects of the short game hard to adjust to in PG (particularly chipping weight) and would welcome the opportunity to be able to go to a practice green, place my ball wherever I wish, and try different clubs, swing types, etc.

I would like to think this is in the works and can appreciate the challenges it may create, however to be ranked a great, if not the greatest golf game, it simply has to be part of the package. Can you imagine arriving at a world class golf resort and discovering there was no practice green. The Horror!
